mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
Arizona’s multiple comprehensive Medicaid managed care programs include overlapping VBP requirements, with the most robust requirements existing in the Acute Care Program. Throughout its contracts, the state emphasizes value-based purchasing as a “cornerstone” of its strategy to bend the upward trajectory of health care costs and health plans must participate in state-required VBP efforts across all programs. Arizona’s various VBP requirements are summarized below.
Alternative Payment Model (APM) Initiative: In calendar year 2019, plans must meet the following APM targets, calculated as a percentage of total Medicaid expenditures. APMs are defined as Health Care Payment Learning and Action Network (HCP-LAN) APM Framework Categories 2B and higher.  
*        Complete Care: 50%
*       ALTCS E/PD: 50%
*        ALTCS IDD sub-contractors for acute services: 38%, LTSS: 10%
*        RBHAs: 
*        Integrated RBHAs for individuals with serious mental illness: 35%
*        Non-integrated, behavioral-health-only RBHAs for other individuals with behavioral health needs: 20% 

These targets increase over the next several years, as follows: 
*        AHCCCS Complete Care (new fully integrated program for adults and children in the Acute Care Program and CRS): 
*        CY 2020: 60%
*        CY 2021: 70%
*        ALTCS E/PD:
*        CY 2020: 60%
*        CY 2021: 70%
*        ALTCS IDD:
*        CY 2020: Sub-contractors for acute services: 50%, LTSS: 20%
*        CY 2021: Sub-contractors for acute services: 60%, LTSS: 35%
*        Integrated RBHAs for individuals with serious mental illness:
*       CY 2020: 50%
*        CY 2021: 60%
*        Non-integrated RBHAs: 
*        CY 2020: 25%
*        CY 2021: 25%

In addition to these APM targets, any Acute Care plans and RBHAs that are affiliated with one another must also enter into at least two APM contracts with integrated providers who offer physical and behavioral health clinical integration for members who are not already integrated under the Acute or RBHA contract but who receive their acute care or behavioral health services from these affiliated entities.

Per the contracts, plans must submit annual APM certification files to the state, demonstrating their compliance or noncompliance with the APM targets. Failure to do so may result in disqualification from participation in the state’s withhold quality measure performance incentive program or the application of sanctions.

* Withhold and Quality Measure Performance Incentive: The state also implements a 1% withhold program and a quality measure performance incentive program that are conditional upon plans meeting the APM targets. Plans failing to meet the APM targets will still have their withhold amount assessed, but will not be eligible for payment under the withhold or incentive programs. Earned withhold and incentive payments will be made to plans based on relative plan performance for the measurement year, as determined by the state. Under the incentive program, plans may receive additional funds over and above the capitation rates for implementing APM arrangements with providers “who successfully meet targets established by the plan that are aimed at quality improvement, such as reducing costs, improving health outcomes, or improving access to care.” 
 
* Value-Based Providers Initiative: Per the contract, plans must develop strategies that ensure that members are “directed to providers who participate in VBP initiatives and who offer value as 
   determined  by measureable outcomes.” Plans must submit annually to the state a “Value-Based Providers/Centers of Excellence” attachment to their Provider Network Development and Management 
   Plans,  describing their strategies to direct their members to high-value providers.

Arizona also permits its managed care plans to design and implement their own physician incentive programs, so long as the incentives are in line with federal requirements and are submitted to the state for approval prior to implementation.

mc_data.name: California
mc_data.title:
Value-Based Payment (VBP) Requirements in
California’s Medicaid Managed Care Program
mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
California’s Medicaid managed care program is a complex program consisting of six discrete
contracting models (see below). VBP requirements across these models are largely aligned. In its
Medicaid managed care contracts for each of these models, California allows—but does not
require—plans to use alternative payment arrangements (e.g., capitation) with network providers
and implement physician incentive plans, provided that they do so in compliance with federal
regulations and state requirements described in the contracts.
*  Two-Plan Model: Twenty-seven counties are designated to operate this model. In each
county, the California Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) contracts with one
county-developed plan called a Local Initiative (LI) and one commercial plan.
*  County Organized Health System (COHS): Twenty-one counties are designated to operate
this model. DHCS contracts with each county and each county operates its own managed
care plan.
*  Regional Model: Nineteen counties are designated to operate this model, which is a slightly
modified version of the Two-Plan approach created for an expansion of Medicaid managed
care into rural counties. In this model, DHCS contracts with two commercial plans per
county.
*  Geographic Managed Care (GMC): Only Sacramento and San Diego counties are
designated to operate this model. DHCS contracts with several commercial plans in these
counties.
* Imperial Model: Only Imperial County is designated to operate this model, which involves
DHCS contracting with two commercial plans.
*  San Benito Model: Only San Benito County is designated to operate this model, which
involves DHCS contracting with one commercial plan and Medi-cal beneficiaries having the
option to enroll in this plan or stay in fee-for-service Medicaid.
Outside its managed care contracts and as part of its 1115 demonstration, California is implementing
a delivery system transformation project called Public Hospital Redesign and Incentives in Medi-Cal

(PRIME), in which success is measured by the increase in percentage of Medi-Cal managed care
payments to public hospitals that are made through VBP arrangements. DHCS has called for 50% of
the Medi-Cal managed care enrollees assigned to a designated public hospital system to have all or
a portion of their costs of care paid through VBP arrangements by January 2018; this percentage will
increase to 55% in January 2019, and to 60% by 2020. Under the PRIME project, four tiers of
capitated payment and other alternative payment models are counted as VBP:
1) partial capitation (primary care only); 2) “partial plus” capitation (primary care and some specialty
care, which can vary by contract); 3) global capitation (primary, specialty, ancillary and/or hospital
care); and 4) additional payment methodologies approved by the state and CMS. Note that the
PRIME project is not currently mentioned in the state’s model contracts.

mc_data.additional_comments:
Colorado is primarily a fee-for-service state, but it has two Medicaid managed care programs serving certain regions: Denver Health Medicaid Choice, serving enrollees in the greater Denver area, and Rocky Mountain Health Plan, serving enrollees in the Western part of the state. 

Per the most recent contract publicly available, the Denver Health Medicaid Choice contract does not require the managed care plan to enter into VBP arrangements with providers, though it does allow for implementation of a physician incentive plan in line with federal requirements, and calls for plans to submit any provider incentives to the state. 

The Rocky Mountain Health Plans Prime (RMHP) program is a part of the state’s [Accountable Care Collaborative (ACC) program](https://www.healthfirstcolorado.com/health-first-colorado-regional-organizations/) that seeks to deliver higher value care to members. RMHP’s model closely resembles a traditional Medicaid managed care program (e.g., the plan enters into a contract with and receives a capitated payment from the state to cover the medical needs of Medicaid enrollees) but has several unique features, including contracting with “Primary Care Medical Providers” that serve as medical homes for members in the ACC program. While the contract emphasizes care coordination and medical home principles, it does not include VBP requirements.

DC also permits (but does not require) its managed care plans to implement district-approved physician incentive plans in line with federal requirements.

mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
Delaware’s contract requires Medicaid managed care plans to enter into state-approved payment arrangements with providers that tie payment to the quality and efficiency of care provided. Specifically, plans must meet annual VBP targets, measured as a percentage of medical/service-related payments out of all expenditures, for all members enrolled in the plan. Under the current contract, the state’s annual VBP targets are as follows:
*        2018: 20% 
*        2019: 30% 
*        2020: 40%
*       2021: 50%
*        2022: 60%

Plans face a financial penalty for each year they do not meet the annual target. For 2018, the penalty was up to 1% of the plans total net revenue received from the state for all populations covered under the contract.  

State-approved VBP arrangements include: 
*        Shared savings
*        Bundled/episodic payments
*        Partial or full risk/capitation/total cost of care
*        Other arrangements “consistent with the overall strategy of paying for value not volume and moving providers to accept risk for the cost/utilization of services”

Additionally, plans may choose, and the state may encourage plans, to implement concurrent delivery system reforms/innovations, such as implementing, developing or contracting with patient-centered medical homes, accountable care organizations or other forms of delivery system changes. 

Per the contract, plans must report on goals and progress with implementing VBP strategies, including an annual planning report explaining goals for the following year, a quarterly progress report describing progress to date, and an annual accomplishment report summarizing the plan’s VBP efforts and results.

Managed care plans may also implement their own physician incentive plans, provided that they are in line with state and federal regulations and are submitted to the state for approval prior to implementation.

mc_data.additional_comments:
Florida’s Medicaid managed care contract does not require plans to enter into VBP arrangements
with network providers, but does allow plans to implement physician incentive plans in line with
federal and state requirements.
Florida state statute1 requires managed care plans to use effective care management to “redirect
available resources and increase compensation for physicians” so that rates for certain services are
equal or exceed the Medicare rates for similar services. In response, the state developed a
physician incentive program, called “MMA Physician Incentive Program” (MPIP), that is designed to
increase compensation for specific physician types who meet certain qualifying criteria, primarily
associated with key access and performance measures. Plans may choose to implement MPIP or
develop and implement their own “Individual Health Plan Incentive Program (IHP),” subject to
approval by the state. The state’s quality strategy frames the MPIP as “movement toward VBP.”

mc_data.name: Georgia
mc_data.title:
Value-Based Payment (VBP) Requirements in
Georgia’s Medicaid Managed Care Program
mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
Georgia requires its Medicaid managed care plans to collaborate with the state to implement a
value-based purchasing (VBP) program—“an enhanced approach to purchasing and program
management that focuses on value over volume” and is “part of a cohesive strategy that aligns
incentives for members, providers, plans and the state.” To support this collaboration, the state
established a Value-Based Purchasing Performance Management Team (PMT), made up of senior
leadership from relevant state agencies and representatives from the plans, with responsibility for
planning, implementing, and executing the VBP initiative and overseeing plans’ VBP programs.
Georgia’s contract calls for the PMT to review each plan’s progress on a regular basis, meet with the
plan at least quarterly, help determine incentive payments, and assess the need to modify VBP
priority areas, measures and targets. Each plan must submit “real-time information” on its VBP
initiatives and provide ongoing and ad hoc reports to the state to show its progress against set
milestones.
The Georgia Families contract describes a “VBP withhold,” under which 5% of plans’ capitation is
withheld pending plans meeting certain performance measures, but the measures are all plan-level
metrics (e.g., HEDIS measures) and not relating to plans’ payment to providers. Managed care plans
must, however, develop a plan for distributing 50% of the VBP withhold payments they receive from
the state to providers, to incentivize or reward their participation in VBP-related efforts. Plans must
submit these “provider collaboration and incentive payment plans” to the state to outline how such
payments will be shared.

mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
Hawaii requires its managed care plans to incorporate “value-driven health care concepts” in their
payment arrangements with providers and meet the following targets for percentage of provider
contracts that are value-driven:
• 50% of plan contracts with primary care providers and hospital contracts in Year 1 (2015)
• 65% of plan contracts with primary care providers and hospital contracts in Year 2 (2016)
• 80% of plan contracts with primary care providers and hospital contracts in Year 3 (2017)
The state’s contract terms outline arrangements that are consistent with “value-driven health care
concepts,” as well as some guardrails for provider payment arrangements:3

• Primary Care Providers: Plans may use the primary care medical home model to facilitate
the provision of high-quality and efficient outpatient care. This model, which is based on
national standards, includes several “domains”: patient-centered care, accessible care,
comprehensive care, coordinated care, evidence-based care, and performance
measurement. Per the contract terms, medical homes must receive increased
reimbursement (under one of two tiers) compared to primary care practices that do not meet
the medical home criteria.
• Hospitals: To incentivize the provision of high-quality and efficient inpatient care, plans may
not reimburse hospitals on a per-diem basis when acuity-adjusted diagnosis-based
reimbursement methodologies exist. (Plans may use per-diem payments for services for
which diagnosis-based reimbursement methodologies are not well-developed and for
specific situations such as those involving wait-listed patients.) All financial incentives for
hospital payments must comply with the Medicare Hospital Value-Based Purchasing
Program.
• Vertically Integrated Organizations: Plans are encouraged to pursue shared risk and
savings programs with integrated care organizations, if available.
Plans ultimately specify the value-driven health care concepts they will incorporate and must submit
a “value-based purchasing plan” to the state for review and approval.

mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
By 2018, Iowa’s managed care plans must have at least 40% of their assigned patient population in
a VBP arrangement with a health care delivery system. VBP arrangements must recognize
population health outcome improvement, as measured through a Value Index Score (VIS), and a
decrease in total cost of care (TCOC) for the population under the arrangement. Per state guidance,
qualifying VBP arrangements include but are not limited to “risk sharing, including both shared
savings and shared costs, between the [plan] and the participating provider organizations, and
bonus payments to providers for improved quality on a population basis.”
Plans must notify the state of any risk-sharing arrangements in place with providers. Plans must also
require that all contracted hospitals report admission and discharge information to the state to
support data exchange and coordination.
Since 2017, plans that achieve annual targets in reduction of TCOC while demonstrating quality
through the VIS are eligible to receive a portion of payment withheld through a pay-for-performance
withhold program.
In addition to the above requirements, Iowa requires plans to establish a “performance-based
incentive system” for its providers. Each plan must design its own methodology for the incentive
program, in line with federal regulations pertaining to physician incentive plans, and must obtain
state approval before implementation and before making any changes. Per Iowa’s contract with
plans, the state “encourages creativity in designing incentive programs that encourage positive
member engagement and health outcomes tailored to issues prevalent among enrolled membership
as identified by the [plan].” Plans must provide information on their incentive programs to enrollees,
upon request, and in any marketing materials as required by federal regulations.

mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
A 2012 state law called for Massachusetts’ Medicaid agency (MassHealth) to implement alternative
payment methodologies (APMs) in its managed care program. The law established requirements
and deadlines for APM adoption, with the overarching goal of having 80% of members receiving
care under an APM by July 2015. While this deadline was not met, the most recent MassHealth
MCO reprocurement cycle contract and delivery system reforms establishing provider-led
MassHealth ACOs continues to support state efforts to expand APMs.
The MassHealth MCO model contract for the period starting March 2018 lays out a timeline for APM
adoption requirements. Per the contract, a minimum proportion of each MCO’s members must
receive care under APMs as follows:
* In contract years 1 and 2 (2018-2019): 60% must receive care under APMs
* In contract years 3 and 4 (2020-2021): 70% must receive care under APMs
* In contract year 5 (2022): 80% must receive care under APMs
The MassHealth MCO contract specifies how the state and MCO may consider a member to be
receiving care under an APM and includes specific reporting requirements. MCOs must provide the
state with the details of their payment methodologies, the algorithms and data used to associate
members to an APM, records of payments made under APMs, and any other documentation that the
state requests.

In addition to the APM targets, the state is launching a new Medicaid ACO program in March 2018,
part of the state’s latest 1115 waiver renewal authorized in 2016. There are three types of providerled MassHealth ACOs: (1) Partnership Plans (joint MCO and ACO prospective risk), (2) Primary Care ACOs (provider-only nearly full retrospective risk), and (3) MCO-Administered ACOs (limited
ACO retrospective risk with support from MCOs for care management). The MassHealth MCO
contract requires MCOs to contract with at least one MCO-Administered ACO, provided there is at
least one in the MCO’s region; such a contract counts toward the MCO’s APM coverage.
The Partnership Plan ACO agreement with the state most closely mirrors a managed care contract,
with the joint MCO-ACO venture (the Partnership Plan) assuming full risk for delivering a
comprehensive set of benefits to Medicaid managed care members, much like a traditional MCO.1
The Partnership Plan contract also includes requirements relating to financial accountability for the
provider-led ACO partner of the joint venture as well as risk-sharing with contracted primary care
providers (PCPs):
* Financial accountability – Per the contract, the Partnership Plan must have a “financial
accountability arrangement” where the MCO holds the ACO financially accountable for the
performance under this contract, with potential for the ACO to receive partial gains or losses.
Under such arrangement, the ACO’s maximum annual potential for losses or gains based on
the joint venture’s performance shall not be less than 5% of the joint venture’s risk-adjusted
medical component of the capitation rate for the contract year.
* PCP-related VBP requirements – The contract also requires the Partnership Plans to:
o Hold PCPs or groups of PCPs financially accountable for performance—PCPs must
have the potential to share gains from savings or share financial responsibility for
losses, such that PCPs “experience a meaningful portion of their annual Medicaid
patient service revenue opportunity tied to value-based performance measures”;
o Make value-based payments based on a performance measurement and
management process specified in the contract; and
o Reduce the influence of volume-based, fee-for-service incentives for PCPs.
Partnership Plans must also submit progress reports that include a description of their value-based
payments to PCPs, the size of the potential gains or losses for each PCP or PCP group, the actual
amount of performance-based gains or losses realized by such PCPs, and the results of the
Partnership Plan’s performance measurement and management strategy for PCPs.
Primary Care ACOs contract directly with the state and have similar PCP risk sharing and reporting
requirements in their contract. MCO-Administered ACOs assume a structured level of risk (three
tracks outlined by the state) with their contracted MCOs for total-cost-of-care performance and also
have PCP-level risk sharing and reporting requirements.

mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
Since 2011, Minnesota has been engaged in a demonstration program, Integrated Health
Partnerships (IHP), to develop and test VBP methodologies with provider organizations through an
agreed-upon total cost of care and shared savings and losses payment arrangement for attributed
populations. Minnesota requires its Medicaid managed care plans to participate in the shared
savings and losses payment methodology for any IHP entities in the plan network. The state’s
contract with the plans further specifies IHP-related data sharing and payment requirements; for
example, the state identifies plans’ enrollees attributed to each IHP entity, provides information on
the total cost of care for the plans’ attributed enrollees, and calculates payments for plans to make to
IHP entities in their networks.
The Minnesota Department of Human Services will be expanding and enhancing this demonstration
in 2018 to introduce multiple tracks that accommodate a diverse set of provider systems, add a
quarterly population-based payment to support care coordination and infrastructure needs, and
modify the quality measurement methodology. The state’s contract with plans will be modified to
reflect these changes as they apply to plans’ participation in VBP arrangements with IHP entities.
Minnesota also has a Health Care Home program, focused on redesigning care delivery and
enabling meaningful patient engagement in care. The state requires its managed care plans to pay a
“care coordination fee” to Health Care Home providers in the plan network or otherwise enter into an
alternative payment arrangement that “includes care coordination and is tied to outcome measures
related to patient health, patient experience and cost effectiveness with that clinic or clinician.”

Missouri requires managed care plans to design and implement state-approved “provider incentive
programs” and to ensure that a minimum of 10% of network providers participate in such programs
by the end of the contract year. Plans must submit to the state certain information about the
incentive programs on a regular basis (e.g., the services covered under such incentive programs,

provider participation in these incentive programs: the state withholds 0.33% of plans’ capitation
payment pending the plan meeting the 10% provider participation target.

Coordination Program” that can include accountable care organizations, patient-centered medical
homes, primary care case management, sub-capitation, a combination of these models or some
other payment and delivery model deployed through local providers, with the goal of increasing care
coordination and improving health outcomes.

mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
New Mexico’s Medicaid managed care contract specifies three “levels” of VBP:
* Level 1: Payment through a fee schedule with bonus payments made based on
outcome/quality scores
*  Level 2: Payment through a fee schedule with upside-only shared savings opportunities and
payment based on outcome/quality scores
• Level 3: Payment through a fee schedule or capitation arrangements with upside and
downside risk, or global payments
Medicaid managed care plans must meet the following VBP targets (called “VBP Level Minimum
Requirements”). Plans must also submit an annual VBP strategy that includes detailed work plans
describing how they intend to meet these targets, along with annual and quarterly VBP reports.
• CY 2019: At least 24% of provider payments must be made through VBP, broken down as
follows:
o Level 1: 8%
o Level 2: 11%
o Level 3: 5%
• CY 2020: At least 30% of provider payments must be made through VBP, broken down as
follows:
o Level 1: 10%
o Level 2: 13%
o Level 3: 7%
• CY 2021: At least 33% of provider payments must be made through VBP, broken down as
follows:
o Level 1: 11%
o Level 2: 14%
o Level 3: 8%
• CY 2022: At least 36% of provider payments must be made through VBP, broken down as
follows:
o Level 1: 12%
o Level 2: 15%
o Level 3: 9%
In addition, New Mexico places 1.5% of plans’ premium at risk based on their ability to meet certain
quality and performance measures, among them the VBP targets. The state uses a point-based
system to calculate how much of the 1.5% withhold a plan earns back in a given year, and points are
deducted if a plan fails to meet any of the VBP targets, does not include a mix of provider types
(e.g., physical health, behavioral health, long-term care) in VBP contracts, and fails to meet VBP
reporting requirements.
Finally, the contract allows plans that do not meet the VBP targets to make proposals to the state to
spend the amount equivalent to their penalty on “system improvement activities for provider network
development and enhancement activities that will directly benefit members.”

mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
New York requires its Medicaid managed care plans to enter into VBP arrangements with network
providers, in accordance with its robust “VBP Roadmap,” which the state updates and submits
annually to CMS. New York’s VBP Roadmap defines VBP by type of payment arrangement and
level of risk, as depicted in the following table. 
Per the VBP Roadmap, plans must meet the following VBP targets:
*  By April 1, 2018, at least 10% of plans’ total expenditures should be captured in “Level 1”
VBP arrangements or higher.
* By April 1, 2019:
* At least 50% of plans’ total expenditures should be captured in “Level 1” VBP
arrangements or higher; and
o At least 15% of plans’ total expenditures should be captured in “Level 2” VBP
arrangements or higher.
* By April 1, 2020:
*  Between 80% and 90% of plans’ total expenditures should be captured in “Level 1”
VBP arrangements or higher; and
* At least 35% of plans’ total expenditures should be captured in “Level 2” VBP
arrangements or higher.
Plans must report regularly on their VBP contracting and submit to the state provider subcontracts
that include VBP arrangements. The state reviews plans’ provider subcontracts based on the degree
of provider risk included in the agreement, classifies each by VBP level, per the VBP Roadmap.
In addition to the VBP targets, New York implements three VBP-related adjustments to plans’
capitated rates to incentivize value-based contracting.
* Stimulus Adjustment: To encourage plans to engage in higher levels of VBP and pass on
more risk to providers, plans will receive an upward “stimulus adjustment” on new Level 2 or
Level 3 VBP arrangements; these adjustments are based on plan-reported VBP survey
results. To qualify for stimulus adjustments, contracts must achieve greater than the 40th
percentile in quality. Stimulus payments will end after State Fiscal Year (SFY) 2019-2020.
*  Penalty Adjustment: New York State is implementing a penalty or downward adjustment for
plans that do not meet the VBP targets outlined in the state’s VBP Roadmap. Penalties are
levied on the value of the difference between the state’s VBP target and the plan’s
contracted amount; these adjustments are based on plan-reported VBP survey results.
*  Performance Adjustment: Plans’ rates will also be adjusted—either upward or downward—
based on the relative quality and efficiency (measured by actual-to-expected cost ratio) per
VBP arrangement (where upward adjustments will be made for contracts showing high
quality and efficiency and downward adjustments will be made for contracts showing lower
quality and efficiency). The state applies rate adjustments for both quality and efficiency to
produce one net performance adjustment score, so that plans may receive up to +/- 1% of
total premium for each adjustment (+/- 2% total); this percentage may gradually increase
over time. Plans will only be eligible for positive performance adjustments if contracts
achieve greater than the 40th percentile in quality. The state sets targets for quality and
efficiency based on historical data.
Finally, New York administers a “VBP Innovator Program” for providers with experience taking risk.
The VBP Innovator Program is a voluntary program for providers prepared for enter into Level 2 and
Level 3 VBP arrangements. VBP Innovator providers are eligible for up to 95% of the total dollars
that have been traditionally paid from the State to plans. Per the model contract, plans are notified of
approved Innovator providers and must amend their subcontracts with these providers to include the
parameters of the program.

mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
Ohio’s Medicaid managed care contract calls for plans to enter into payment arrangements with
providers that promote patient-centered care delivery, reduce disparities, and encourage alignment
between public and private sectors. Specifically, the state requires plans to design and implement
VBP models with providers that are “value-oriented”—designed to “cut waste” (reduce unnecessary
utilization and/or payment) or “reflect value” (increase the quality of care for the cost). Per the
contract, plans must develop and submit to the state a VBP strategy that describes how they will
make 50% of their provider payments "value-oriented” by 2020. Plans must also submit quarterly
reports showing their progress towards the 50% threshold. Strategies for meeting this threshold
include:
* Paying providers differentially according to performance;
* Designing and implementing payment approaches that reduce waste while not diminishing
quality;
* Developing payment strategies to minimize unwarranted price variation, such as referenceor value-based pricing; and,
* Structuring payments to encourage adherence to clinical guidelines.

mc_data.name: Oregon
mc_data.title:
Value-Based Payment (VBP) Requirements in
Oregon’s Medicaid Managed Care Program
mc_data.program_name: Oregon Health Plan, Coordinated Care Organizations
mc_data.additional_sources_of_vbp_requirements:
Approved Medicaid 1115 Demonstration Special Terms
and Conditions (STCs), January 2017
mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
Through 2012 state legislation and a subsequent 1115 waiver, Oregon launched Coordinated Care
Organizations (CCOs), which are community-based partnerships of managed care organizations
and providers that receive a global budget from the state to manage care for a defined Medicaid
population. CCOs manage risk in the same way as managed care organizations, but have a
governance structure that includes providers and community members.
Oregon’s contract with CCOs includes the following VBP-related requirements:
* CCOs must demonstrate how they will use “alternative payment methodologies” alone or in
combination with delivery system changes to achieve better care, controlled costs and better
health for enrollees. To do so, CCOs must implement a “schedule of alternative payments,
with benchmarks and evaluation points identified that demonstrate direct support for
transformation of care delivery and the sustainability of care innovations across the care
continuum.”
*The CCO contract requires implementation of alternative payment methodologies with statedesignated Patient Centered Primary Care Homes, entities established by the state
legislature that CCOs must include in their networks to the maximum extent possible.
* Further, the contract requires state-approved CCO “Transformation Plans” that demonstrate
how and when the CCO will achieve health system transformation; Transformation Plans
must include a section on implementation of alternative payment methodologies that align
with health outcomes.
* The contract defines “alternative payment methodology” as payment other than a fee-forservices payment, used by the CCO as compensation for the provision of integrated and
coordinated health care and services, and including but not limiting to: shared savings
arrangements; bundled arrangements; payments based on episodes; risk sharing withhold;
quality incentive payments; and access improvement payments.
In addition to these contract requirements, Oregon’s 1115 waiver calls for the state to ensure
through its CCO contracts that VBP arrangements, structured to improve quality and manage cost
growth, are used by CCOs with their network providers. Per the waiver, Oregon must develop a
“VBP plan” that describes how the state, CCOs and network providers will achieve a “set target of VBP payments” by the end of the waiver period, though no targets have been made public by the
state at this time. The waiver includes several other requirements on this VBP plan (e.g., what it
must include and how it must be developed).

mc_data.name: Pennsylvania
mc_data.title:
Value-Based Payment (VBP) Requirements in
Pennsylvania’s Medicaid Managed Care Program
mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
Pennsylvania requires its managed care plans to enter into payment arrangements with providers
that incorporate different types of VBP strategies, including:
(i) Pay-for-performance programs,
(ii) Patient-centered medical homes,
(iii) Shared savings arrangements,
(iv) Bundled or global payment arrangements, and
(v) Full-risk or accountable care organization payment arrangements.
In addition, plans must meet the following VBP targets:
* In 2017: 7.5% of the medical portion of the plan’s premium and maternity care revenue must
be expended through any of the listed VBP strategies.
* In 2018: The percentage increases to 15% and at least half of the 15% must be from a
combination of strategies (ii) through (v).
* In 2019: The percentage increases to 30% and at least half of the 30% must be from a
combination of strategies (iii) through (v).
Pennsylvania requires each managed care plan to submit, by January 1st of each year, a “proposed
VBP plan” describing its strategy for meeting the state’s targets in the upcoming year. Plans must
also submit quarterly progress reports, and by June 30th of the subsequent year, a report on “VBP
accomplishments” from the prior year. The VBP accomplishment reports must list VBP
arrangements by provider and describe each arrangement, including the specific dollar amounts in
each VBP strategy. If the state determines that a plan is not compliant based on its review of the
VBP accomplishments report, the plan’s next monthly premium payment is reduced by an amount
equivalent to 1% of the plan’s premium for December of the prior year.

mc_data.additional_comments:
Of note, Pennsylvania conducted a re-procurement of its managed care plans in 2016 and faced a
number of implementation delays. The new contract terms released as part of this re-procurement
are scheduled to roll out over 2018 and 2019. The only significant changes to the state’s VBP
requirements relate to the penalty assessed when plans are determined to be noncompliant with the
state’s VBP requirements. Per the new contract terms, the state will reduce a noncompliant plan’s monthly premium payment by 2% (instead of 1%) for up to twelve months (instead of just one
month); the state has restructured this penalty as a “Holdback” program (similar to a withhold) where
the state will pay return Holdbacks it has retrained for a given plan if it subsequently determines that
the plan is in compliance with the current goal for any year. (If this determination is made, the state
will also discontinue Holdbacks applicable to a previous year.) The state may also elect to
discontinue further Holdbacks or repay Holdbacks in part or in full if it determines that a plan has
made substantial and meaningful efforts to accomplish the VBP goals

mc_data.name: South Carolina
mc_data.title:
Value-Based Payment (VBP) Requirements in South
Carolina’s Medicaid Managed Care Program
mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
South Carolina requires 30% of all managed care plan payments to providers to be made through alternative payment models (APMs), described in the contract as “pay-for-performance, episodes of care, shared savings arrangements, shared risk arrangements, and/or capitation payments with performance and quality requirements.”  The state has adopted the [Health Care Payment Learning and Action Network (HCP LAN) alternative payment model (APM) framework](https://hcp-lan.org/groups/apm-fpt-work-products/apm-framework/) and defines qualifying APMs as HCP LAN category 2C or higher. 

Each year, plans must submit certifications of the percent of expenditures made through APMs, including a listing of payment amounts associated with each HCP-LAN category. The state withholds up to 1.5% of the plan’s premium pending the plan meeting various quality and performance metrics, one of which is the APM target. Plans that do not meet the state’s APM target for the year forfeit 25% of withheld funds.

mc_data.name: Tennessee
mc_data.title:
Value-Based Payment (VBP) Requirements in
Tennessee’s Medicaid Managed Care Program
mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
Tennessee requires its Medicaid managed care plans to participate in its multi-payer payment
reform program, the “Tennessee Health Care Innovation Initiative,” which includes several
components: episode-based payments, patient-centered medical homes, and a care coordination
program called Tennessee Health Link.
As part of this initiative, plans must implement episode-based payments with network providers as
directed by the state (which entails implementing around three to six new episodes per quarter). If
the average cost of the episode of care is below a pre-determined level, the plan must pay the lead
provider a share of the savings achieved. Conversely, if the average cost is above a pre-determined
level, the lead provider is required to pay part of the excess cost. The state is aiming to implement
75 episodes by the end of 2019.
Per the contract, a plan’s failure to implement state payment reform programs as directed by the
state may result in the plan “forfeiting savings that would have been realized based on the timely
implementation.”
Tennessee also requires its plans to submit any additional physician incentive plans to the state for
approval prior to implementation.

Medicaid Managed Care Program

*STAR+PLUS (covers individuals who have disabilities or are ages 65 or older)
* STAR+PLUS Medicaid Rural Service Area (covers rural areas with limited providers)

mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
Across its Medicaid managed care programs, Texas requires managed care plans to develop and
execute written, state-approved plans for expanding VBP with network providers and transition
payments to providers from traditional fee-for-service arrangements to alternative payment models
(APMs). Per the contract, APMs should be designed to “improve health outcomes for members,
empower members and improve experience of care, lower healthcare cost trends, and incentivize
providers.” Plans must meet the following APM-related requirements:
* Annual APM Targets: Achieve minimum levels of APMs (calculated as percentages or
ratios of all provider payments) and risk-based APM ratios, as follows:
* In Calendar Year (CY) 2018:
* Achieve an overall APM ratio of at least 25% of provider payments
* Achieve a risk-based APM ratio of at least 10% of provider payments
* In CY 2019: Achieve increase of 125% compared to CY 2018 targets
* In CY 2020: Achieve an increase of 125% compared to CY 2019 targets
* In CY 2021:
* Achieve an overall APM ratio of at least 50% of provider payments
* Achieve a risk-based APM ratio of at least 25% of provider payments
Failure to meet these APM targets results in penalties of up to $0.10 per member per month
for the period of measurement. Plans not meeting APM targets may also be subject to
corrective action plans.
*APM Reporting: Submit to the state an annual inventory of APMs with providers, to
calculate APM ratios.
* Data Sharing: Implement processes to regularly share data and performance reports with
providers.
* APM Evaluation: Dedicate resources to evaluate the impact of APMs on utilization, quality,
and cost, as well as return on investment.
* Gain Sharing Pilots: Submit to the state gain-sharing pilot programs that would reward
providers for decreasing inappropriate utilization of services. Proposals must include
mechanisms through which the plan will provide incentive payments to hospitals and
physicians for high-quality care and must stipulate the quality metrics required for incentives,
provider recruitment strategies, and a proposed structure for payment.

mc_data.name: Virginia
mc_data.title:
Value-Based Payment (VBP) Requirements in
Virginia’s Medicaid Managed Care Program
mc_data.program_name:
* Medallion 3.0 (the state’s traditional Medicaid managed care program)
*Commonwealth Coordinated Care Plus (“CCC Plus,” a new Medicaid managed long term
services and supports program
mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
Virginia requires its Medicaid managed care plans (including both Medallion 3.0 and CCC Plus
plans) to maintain and implement a VBP strategy that follows the alternate payment model (APM)
framework developed by the Health Care Payment Learning and Action Network (HCP LAN), with a
special emphasis on development, adoption, and provider readiness for models under APM
categories 3 (shared savings, or shared savings and downside risk) and 4 (population-based
payments). Plans must develop and submit to the state detailed VBP Plans outlining their VBP
strategy, that addresses current state and strategies for the entire 18 months of the contract
including “how the plan expects to maintain, expand, and enhance VBP arrangements during the
contract period.” VBP Plans must feature the following:
*Current state review:
*An overview of all provider APM agreements, by HCP-LAN framework category;
* The percentage of total and Medicaid-specific medical expenses paid under each
APM type and a comparison to the previous calendar year; and
* Lessons learned and results from any APMs in place for over one year.
* Provider readiness, performance reviews, and communication approach (including methods
and frequency of data collection from providers).
* Written strategy related to three APMs expected to be most effective for services and
populations covered under the contract, specific objectives for APM implementation, and the
relationship between Medicaid VBP efforts and the plan’s VBP strategies in other markets
(e.g., commercial, Medicare).

Plans must also submit VBP Status Reports detailing each of the plan’s VBP initiatives. Nine
metrics are required in these reports: APM category, initiative description, goals and results, targeted
members, targeted providers, total plan spending, total plan payments made to providers under the
VBP initiative, potential payment adjustments, and potential overlap with other VBP initiatives. Plans
must also complete and submit to the state an APM data collection tool with quantitative data about
their VBP arrangements with providers, organized by APM categories.
In addition to these VBP reporting requirements, Virginia’s Medallion 3.0 contract stipulates that
Medallion 3.0 plans must operationalize at least one Medallion Care System Partnership (MCSP)
that targets, at a minimum, pediatric populations and coordinates acute and/or behavioral health
services. As part of these MCSPs, plans must enter into contractual arrangements with providers
that include:
* Gain and/or risk sharing;
* Performance-based incentives; and/or,
* Other incentive reforms tied to state-approved quality metrics and financial performance.
Approved MCSP programs are pre-determined models and payment arrangements, ranging from
pay-for-performance to vertical capitation for total cost of care. (See page 162 of the contract for
more details.) A single MCSP may use a combination of model options and payment types. Plans
must report incentives and performance results to the state on an annual basis.
Finally, the CCC Plus contract notes that beginning in the Calendar Year 2019 contract year, the
state intends to set specific targets for VBP categories 2-4 and that CCC Plus plans should expect to
see targets increase by at least five percentage points each year thereafter. Similarly, the state has
released its Request for Proposals (RFP) for Medallion 4.0, the next iteration of the state’s traditional
Medicaid managed care program, and it notes the state’s intent to set specific VBP targets in the
future. Per the RFP, the portion of plans’ medical expenditures captured through VBP arrangements
shall either increase by at least 20% by the end of year three of the future contract, or represent at
least 50% of the plan’s total medical expenditures by the end of year three of the future contract.

mc_data.name: Washington
mc_data.title:
Value-Based Payment (VBP) Requirements in
Washington’s Medicaid Managed Care Program
mc_data.summary_of_the_state_vbp_requirements:
In January 2017, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) approved Washington’s Medicaid transformation demonstration, a key goal of which is to accelerate the transition to VBP in the state’s Medicaid managed care program. The demonstration, which references the national Health Care Payment Learning and Action Network (HCP LAN) alternative payment model (APM) framework, calls for Washington’s Medicaid managed care plans to meet the following VBP targets. 
*       By the end of 2017: 30% of payments to providers were to be made through payment arrangements described by the HCP LAN to be “Category 2C” (Rewards for Performance) or higher.
*        By the end of 2018: 50% of payments to providers were to be made through payment arrangements described by the HCP LAN to be “Category 2C” or higher., and 10% of payments to providers must be made through payment arrangements described by the HCP LAN to be “Category 3A” (APMs with upside gainsharing) or higher.
*       By the end of 2019: 75% of payments to providers must be made through payment arrangements described by the HCP LAN to be “Category 2C” or higher, and 20% of payments to providers must be made through payment arrangements described by the HCP LAN to be “Category 3A” or higher.
*      By the end of 2020: 85% of payments to providers must be made through payment arrangements described by the HCP LAN to be “Category 2C” or higher, and 30% of payments to providers must be made through payment arrangements described by the HCP LAN to be “Category 3A” or higher.
*        By the end of 2021: 90% of payments to providers must be made through payment arrangements described by the HCP LAN to be “Category 2C” or higher, and 50% of payments to providers must be made through payment arrangements described by the HCP LAN to be “Category 3A” or higher.

Washington also places a portion of the plans’ premium at risk based on plans’ ability to meet these VBP targets. The state’s contract with plans describes its premium withhold program, in which specified percentages of plans’ premium are conditional upon plans meeting the state’s VBP targets and making “qualifying provider incentive payments tied to quality.” The withhold also includes a plan-level quality improvement component as well.

The state’s contract also requires plans to participate in local Accountable Communities of Health (ACHs) and specifically to collaborate with ACHs and participating providers to implement VBP models.
